1.1: This letter is from Paul. I am a servant owned by Jesus Christ and a missionary chosen by God to preach His Good News.
1.2: The Good News was promised long ago by God’s early preachers in His Holy Writings.
1.3: It tells of His Son, our Lord Jesus Christ, Who was born as a person in the flesh through the family of King David.
1.4: The Holy Spirit proved by a powerful act that Jesus our Lord is the Son of God because He was raised from the dead.
1.5: Jesus has given us His loving-favor and has made us His missionaries. We are to preach to the people of all nations that they should obey Him and put their trust in Him.
1.6: You have been chosen to belong to Jesus Christ also.
1.7: So I write to all of you in the city of Rome. God loves you and has chosen you to be set apart for Himself. May God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ give you His loving-favor and peace.
1.8: First of all, I keep thanking my God, through Jesus Christ, for all of you. This is because the whole world knows of your faith in Christ.
1.9: God knows how I work for Him. He knows how I preach with all my heart the Good News about His Son. He knows how I always pray for you.
1.10: I pray that I might be able to visit you, if God wants me to.
1.11: I want to see you so I can share some special gift of the Holy Spirit with you. It will make you strong.
1.12: Both of us need help. I can help make your faith strong and you can do the same for me. We need each other.
1.13: Christian brothers, many times I have wanted to visit you. Something has kept me from going until now. I have wanted to lead some of you to Christ also, as I have done in other places where they did not know God.
1.14: I must help the people who have had a chance to hear the Good News and those who have not. I must help those with much learning and those who have never learned from books.
1.15: So I want to preach the Good News to you who live in Rome also.
1.16: I am not ashamed of the Good News. It is the power of God. It is the way He saves men from the punishment of their sins if they put their trust in Him. It is for the Jew first and for all other people also.
1.17: The Good News tells us we are made right with God by faith in Him. Then, by faith we live that new life through Him. The Holy Writings say, “A man right with God lives by faith.”
1.18: We see the anger of God coming down from heaven against all the sins of men. These sinful men keep the truth from being known.
1.19: Men know about God. He has made it plain to them.
1.20: Men cannot say they do not know about God. From the beginning of the world, men could see what God is like through the things He has made. This shows His power that lasts forever. It shows that He is God.
1.21: They did know God, but they did not honor Him as God. They were not thankful to Him and thought only of foolish things. Their foolish minds became dark.
1.22: They said that they were wise, but they showed how foolish they were.
1.23: They gave honor to false gods that looked like people who can die and to birds and animals and snakes. This honor belongs to God Who can never die.
1.24: So God let them follow the desires of their sinful hearts. They did sinful things among themselves with their bodies.
1.25: They traded the truth of God for a lie. They worshiped and cared for what God made instead of worshiping the God Who made it. He is the One Who is to receive honor and thanks forever. Let it be so.
1.26: Because of this, God let them follow their sinful desires which lead to shame. Women used their bodies in ways God had not planned.
1.27: In the same way, men left the right use of women’s bodies. They did sex sins with other men. They received for themselves the punishment that was coming to them for their sin.
1.28: Because they would not keep God in their thoughts anymore, He gave them up. Their minds were sinful and they wanted only to do things they should not do.
1.29: They are full of everything that is sinful and want things that belong to others. They hate people and are jealous. They kill other people. They fight and lie. They do not like other people and talk against them.
1.30: They talk about people, and they hate God. They are filled with pride and tell of all the good they do. They think of new ways to sin. They do not obey their parents.
1.31: They are not able to understand. They do not do what they say they will do. They have no love and no loving-pity.
1.32: They know God has said that all who do such things should die. But they keep on doing these things and are happy when others do them also.

2.1: So you can say nothing because you are guilty when you say someone else is guilty. While you say someone is guilty, you are doing the same things he does.
2.2: We know that God will say those who do such things are guilty.
2.3: Do you think God will punish others for doing wrong and let you keep sinning?
2.4: Do you forget about His loving-kindness to you? Do you forget how long He is waiting for you? You know that God is kind. He is trying to get you to be sorry for your sins and turn from them.
2.5: Because you are not sorry for your sins and will not turn from them, you will be punished even more on the day of God’s anger. God will be right in saying you are guilty.
2.6: He will give to every man what he should get for the things he has done.
2.7: Those who keep on doing good and are looking for His greatness and honor will receive life that lasts forever.
2.8: Those who love only themselves and do not obey the truth, but do what is wrong, will be punished by God. His anger will be on them.
2.9: Every Jew and every person who is not a Jew who sins will suffer and have great sorrow.
2.10: But God will give His greatness and honor and peace to all those who obey the truth. Both Jews and those who are not Jews will receive this.
2.11: God does not show favor to one man more than to another.
2.12: Those who have sinned without having the Law will be lost without the Law being used. Those who have the Law and have sinned will be judged by the Law.
2.13: Just to hear the Law does not make a man right with God. The man right with God is the one who obeys the Law.
2.14: The people who are not Jews do not have the Law. When they do what the Law tells them to do, even if they do not have the Law, it shows they know what they should do.
2.15: They show that what the Law wants them to do is written in their hearts. Their own hearts tell them if they are guilty.
2.16: There will be a day when God will judge because He knows the secret thoughts of men. He will do this through Jesus Christ. This is part of the Good News I preach.
2.17: You are a Jew and think you are safe because of the Law. You tell others about how you know God.
2.18: You know what He wants you to do. You understand how the Law works. You know right from wrong.
2.19: You think you can lead a blind man. You think you can give light to those in darkness.
2.20: You think you can teach foolish people and children about God. You have in the Law the plan of truth and wisdom.
2.21: You teach others. Why do you not teach yourselves? You tell others not to steal. Do you steal?
2.22: You say that no one should do sex sins. Do you do sex sins? You hate false gods. Do you rob the houses where they are kept?
2.23: You are proud of the Law. Do you take honor away from God when you do not obey the Law?
2.24: The Holy Writings say, “God’s name is hated by the people who are not Jews because of you.”
2.25: Going through the religious act of becoming a Jew is worth something if you obey the Law. If you do not obey the Law, it is worth nothing to you.
2.26: If a person who is not a Jew and has not gone through the act of becoming a Jew, obeys the Law, God will think of him as a Jew.
2.27: You Jews have the Law but do not obey it. You have gone through the religious act also. At the same time those who are not Jews obey the Law even if they have not gone through the religious act of becoming a Jew. In this way, these people show you are guilty.
2.28: A man is not a Jew just because he goes through the religious act of becoming a Jew.
2.29: The true Jew is one whose heart is right with God. The religious act of becoming a Jew must be done in the heart. That is the work of the Holy Spirit. The Law does not do that kind of work. The true Jew gets his thanks from God, not from men.

3.1: Do the Jews have anything that those who are not Jews do not have? What good does it do to go through the religious act of becoming a Jew?
3.2: Yes, the Jews have much more in every way. First of all, God gave the Jews His Law.
3.3: If some of them were not faithful, does it mean that God will not be faithful?
3.4: No, not at all! God is always true even if every man lies. The Holy Writings say, “Speak the truth and you will not be proven guilty.”
3.5: If our sins show how right God is, what can we say? Is it wrong for God to punish us for it? (I am speaking as men do.)
3.6: No, not at all! If it were wrong for God to punish us, how could He judge the world?
3.7: If my lies honor God by showing how true He is, why am I still being judged as a sinner?
3.8: Why not say, “Let us sin that good will come from it.” (Some people have said I talk like this!) They will be punished as they should be.
3.9: What about it then? Are we Jews better than the people who are not Jews? Not at all! I have already said that Jews and the people who are not Jews are all sinners.
3.10: The Holy Writings say, “There is not one person who is right with God. No, not even one!
3.11: There is not one who understands. There is not one who tries to find God.”
3.12: Everyone has turned away from God. They have all done wrong. Not one of them does what is good. No, not even one!
3.13: Their mouth is like an open grave. They tell lies with their tongues. Whatever they say is like the poison of snakes.
3.14: Their mouths speak bad things against God. They say bad things about other people.
3.15: They are quick to hurt and kill people.
3.16: Wherever they go, they destroy and make people suffer.
3.18: They do not honor God with love and fear.”
3.19: Now we know that the Law speaks to those who live under the Law. No one can say that he does not know what sin is. Yes, every person in the world stands guilty before God.
3.20: No person will be made right with God by doing what the Law says. The Law shows us how sinful we are.
3.21: But now God has made another way to make men right with Himself. It is not by the Law. The Law and the early preachers tell about it.
3.22: Men become right with God by putting their trust in Jesus Christ. God will accept men if they come this way. All men are the same to God.
3.23: For all men have sinned and have missed the shining-greatness of God.
3.24: Anyone can be made right with God by the free gift of His loving-favor. It is Jesus Christ Who bought them with His blood and made them free from their sins.
3.25: God gave Jesus Christ to the world. Men’s sins can be forgiven through the blood of Christ when they put their trust in Him. God gave His Son Jesus Christ to show how right He is. Before this, God did not look on the sins that were done.
3.26: But now God proves that He is right in saving men from sin. He shows that He is the One Who has no sin. God makes anyone right with Himself who puts his trust in Jesus.
3.27: What then do we have to be proud of? Nothing at all! Why? Is it because men obey the Law? No! It is because men put their trust in Christ.
3.28: This is what we have come to know. A man is made right with God by putting his trust in Christ. It is not by his doing what the Law says.
3.29: Is God the God of the Jews only? Is He not the God of the people who are not Jews also? He is for sure.
3.30: He is one God. He will make Jews and the people who are not Jews right with Himself if they put their trust in Christ.
3.31: Does this mean that we do away with the Law when we put our trust in Christ? No, not at all. It means we know the Law is important.

4.1: What about Abraham, our early father? What did he learn?
4.2: If Abraham was made right with God by what he did, he would have had something to be proud of. But he could not be proud before God.
4.3: The Holy Writings say, “Abraham put his trust in God and that made him right with God.”
4.4: If a man works, his pay is not a gift. It is something he has earned.
4.5: If a man has not worked to be saved, but has put his trust in God Who saves men from the punishment of their sins, that man is made right with God because of his trust in God.
4.6: David tells of this. He spoke of how happy the man is who puts his trust in God without working to be saved from the punishment of sin.
4.7: “Those people are happy whose sinful acts are forgiven and whose sins are covered.
4.8: Those people are happy whose sins the Lord will not remember.”
4.9: Is this happiness given to the Jews only? Or is it given also to the people who are not Jews? We say again, “Abraham put his trust in God and that made him right with God.”
4.10: When did this happen? Was it before or after Abraham went through the religious act of becoming a Jew? It was before.
4.11: He went through the religious act after he had put his trust in God. That religious act proved that his trust in God made him right with God even before he went through the religious act of becoming a Jew. In that way, it made him the early father of all those who believe. It showed that those who did not go through the religious act of becoming a Jew could be right with God.
4.12: He is also the early father of all those who have gone through the religious act of becoming a Jew. It is not because they went through the act. It is because they put their trust in God the same as Abraham did before he went through the religious act of becoming a Jew.
4.13: God promised to give the world to him and to all his family after him. He did not make this promise because Abraham obeyed the Law. He promised to give the world to Abraham because he put his trust in God. This made him right with God.
4.14: If those who obey the Law are to get the world, then a person putting his trust in God means nothing. God’s promise to Abraham would be worth nothing.
4.15: God’s anger comes on a man when he does not obey the Law. But if there were no Law, then no one could break it.
4.16: So God’s promise is given to us because we put our trust in Him. We can be sure of it. It is because of His loving-favor to us. It is for all the family of Abraham. It is for those who obey the Law. It is for those who put their trust in God as Abraham did. In this way, he is the father of all Christians.
4.17: The Holy Writings say, “I have made you a father of many nations.” This promise is good because of Who God is. He makes the dead live again. He speaks, and something is made out of nothing.
4.18: Abraham believed he would be the father of many nations. He had no reason to hope for this, but he had been told, “Your children will become many nations.”
4.19: Abraham was about one hundred years old. His body was about dead, but his faith in God was not weak when he thought of his body. His faith was not weak when he thought of his wife Sarah being past the age of having children.
4.20: Abraham did not doubt God’s promise. His faith in God was strong, and he gave thanks to God.
4.21: He was sure God was able to do what He had promised.
4.22: Abraham put his trust in God and was made right with Him.
4.23: The words, “He was made right with God,” were not for Abraham only.
4.24: They were for us also. God will make us right with Himself the same way He did Abraham, if we put our trust in God Who raised Jesus our Lord from the dead.
4.25: Jesus died for our sins. He was raised from the dead to make us right with God.

5.1: Now that we have been made right with God by putting our trust in Him, we have peace with Him. It is because of what our Lord Jesus Christ did for us.
5.2: By putting our trust in God, He has given us His loving-favor and has received us. We are happy for the hope we have of sharing the shining-greatness of God.
5.3: We are glad for our troubles also. We know that troubles help us learn not to give up.
5.4: When we have learned not to give up, it shows we have stood the test. When we have stood the test, it gives us hope.
5.5: Hope never makes us ashamed because the love of God has come into our hearts through the Holy Spirit Who was given to us.
5.6: We were weak and could not help ourselves. Then Christ came at the right time and gave His life for all sinners.
5.7: No one is willing to die for another person, but for a good man someone might be willing to die.
5.8: But God showed His love to us. While we were still sinners, Christ died for us.
5.9: Now that we have been saved from the punishment of sin by the blood of Christ, He will save us from God’s anger also.
5.10: We hated God. But we were saved from the punishment of sin by the death of Christ. He has brought us back to God and we will be saved by His life.
5.11: Not only that, we give thanks to God through our Lord Jesus Christ. Through Him we have been brought back to God.
5.12: This is what happened: Sin came into the world by one man, Adam. Sin brought death with it. Death spread to all men because all have sinned.
5.13: Sin was in the world before the Law was given. But sin is not held against a person when there is no Law.
5.14: And yet death had power over men from the time of Adam until the time of Moses. Even the power of death was over those who had not sinned in the same way Adam sinned. Adam was like the One Who was to come.
5.15: God’s free gift is not like the sin of Adam. Many people died because of the sin of this one man, Adam. But the loving-favor of God came to many people also. This gift came also by one Man Jesus Christ, God’s Son.
5.16: The free gift of God is not like Adam’s sin. God told Adam he was guilty because of his sin and through this one came sin and guilt. But the free gift makes men right with God. Through One, Christ, men’s sins are forgiven.
5.17: The power of death was over all men because of the sin of one man, Adam. But many people will receive His loving-favor and the gift of being made right with God. They will have power in life by Jesus Christ.
5.18: Through Adam’s sin, death and hell came to all men. But another Man, Christ, by His right act makes men free and gives them life.
5.19: Adam did not obey God, and many people become sinners through him. Christ obeyed God and makes many people right with Himself.
5.20: Sin spread when the Law was given. But where sin spread, God’s loving-favor spread all the more.
5.21: Sin had power that ended in death. Now, God’s loving-favor has power to make men right with Himself. It gives life that lasts forever. Our Lord Jesus Christ did this for us.

6.1: What does this mean? Are we to keep on sinning so that God will give us more of His loving-favor?
6.2: No, not at all! We are dead to sin. How then can we keep on living in sin?
6.3: All of us were baptized to show we belong to Christ. We were baptized first of all to show His death.
6.4: We were buried in baptism as Christ was buried in death. As Christ was raised from the dead by the great power of God, so we will have new life also.
6.5: If we have become one with Christ in His death, we will be one with Him in being raised from the dead to new life.
6.6: We know that our old life, our old sinful self, was nailed to the cross with Christ. And so the power of sin that held us was destroyed. Sin is no longer our boss.
6.7: When a man is dead, he is free from the power of sin.
6.8: And if we have died with Christ, we believe we will live with Him also.
6.9: We know that Christ was raised from the dead. He will never die again. Death has no more power over Him.
6.10: He died once but now lives. He died to break the power of sin, and the life He now lives is for God.
6.11: You must do the same thing! Think of yourselves as dead to the power of sin. But now you have new life because of Jesus Christ our Lord. You are living this new life for God.
6.12: So do not let sin have power over your body here on earth. You must not obey the body and let it do what it wants to do.
6.13: Do not give any part of your body for sinful use. Instead, give yourself to God as a living person who has been raised from the dead. Give every part of your body to God to do what is right.
6.14: Sin must not have power over you. You are not living by the Law. You have life because of God’s loving-favor.
6.15: What are we to do then? Are we to sin because we have God’s loving-favor and are not living by the Law? No, not at all!
6.16: Do you not know that when you give yourself as a servant to be owned by someone, that one becomes your owner? If you give yourself to sin, the end is death. If you give yourself to God, the end is being right with Him.
6.17: At one time you were held by the power of sin. But now you obey with all your heart the teaching that was given to you. Thank God for this!
6.18: You were made free from the power of sin. Being right with God has power over you now.
6.19: I speak with words easy to understand because your human thinking is weak. At one time you gave yourselves over to the power of sin. You kept on sinning all the more. Now give yourselves over to being right with God. Set yourself apart for God-like living and to do His work.
6.20: When sin had power over your life, you were not right with God.
6.21: What good did you get from the things you are ashamed of now? Those things bring death.
6.22: But now you are free from the power of sin. You have become a servant for God. Your life is set apart for God-like living. The end is life that lasts forever.
6.23: You get what is coming to you when you sin. It is death! But God’s free gift is life that lasts forever. It is given to us by our Lord Jesus Christ.

7.1: Christian brothers, I am sure you understand what I am going to say. You know all about the Law. The Law has power over a man as long as he lives.
7.2: A married woman is joined by law to her husband as long as he lives. But if he dies, she is free from the law that joined her to him.
7.3: If she marries another man while her husband is still alive, she is sinning by not being faithful in marriage. If her husband dies, she is free from the law that joined her to him. After that she can marry someone else. She does not sin if she marries another man.
7.4: My Christian brothers, that is the way it is with you. You were under the power of the Law. But now you are dead to it because you are joined to another. You are joined to Christ Who was raised from the dead. This is so we may be what God wants us to be. Our lives are to give fruit for Him.
7.5: When we lived to please our bodies, those sinful desires were pulling at us all the time. We always wanted to do what the Law said not to do. Living that kind of life brings death,
7.6: but now we are free from the Law. We are dead to sin that once held us in its power. No longer do we follow the Law which is the old way. We now follow the new way, the way of the Spirit.
7.7: Then what are we saying? Is the Law sinful? No, not at all! But it was the Law that showed me what sin is. I did not know it was sin to follow wrong desires, but the Law said, “You must not follow wrong desires.”
7.8: The Law made me know how much I was sinning. It showed me how I had a desire for all kinds of things. For without the Law, sin is dead.
7.9: I was once alive. That was when I did not know what the Law said I had to do. Then I found that I had broken the Law. I knew I was a sinner. Death was mine because of the Law.
7.10: The Law was supposed to give me new life. Instead, it gave me death.
7.11: Sin found a way to trap me by working through the Law. Then sin killed me by using the Law.
7.12: The Law is holy. Each one of the Laws is holy and right and good.
7.13: Then does it mean that the Law, which is good, brought death to me? No, not at all! It was sin that did it. Sin brought death to me by the Law that is good. In that way, sin was shown to be what it is. So because of the Law, sin becomes much more sinful.
7.14: We know that the Law is right and good, but I am a person who does what is wrong and bad. I am not my own boss. Sin is my boss.
7.15: I do not understand myself. I want to do what is right but I do not do it. Instead, I do the very thing I hate.
7.16: When I do the thing I do not want to do, it shows me that the Law is right and good.
7.17: So I am not doing it. Sin living in me is doing it.
7.18: I know there is nothing good in me, that is, in my flesh. For I want to do good but I do not.
7.19: I do not do the good I want to do. Instead, I am always doing the sinful things I do not want to do.
7.20: If I am always doing the very thing I do not want to do, it means I am no longer the one who does it. It is sin that lives in me.
7.21: This has become my way of life: When I want to do what is right, I always do what is wrong.
7.22: My mind and heart agree with the Law of God.
7.23: But there is a different law at work deep inside of me that fights with my mind. This law of sin holds me in its power because sin is still in me.
7.24: There is no happiness in me! Who can set me free from my sinful old self?
7.25: God’s Law has power over my mind, but sin still has power over my sinful old self. I thank God I can be free through Jesus Christ our Lord!

8.1: Now, because of this, those who belong to Christ will not suffer the punishment of sin.
8.2: The power of the Holy Spirit has made me free from the power of sin and death. This power is mine because I belong to Christ Jesus.
8.3: The Law could not make me free from the power of sin and death. It was weak because it had to work with weak human beings. But God sent His own Son. He came to earth in a body of flesh which could be tempted to sin as we in our bodies can be. He gave Himself to take away sin. By doing that, He took away the power sin had over us.
8.4: In that way, Jesus did for us what the Law said had to be done. We do not do what our sinful old selves tell us to do anymore. Now we do what the Holy Spirit wants us to do.
8.5: Those who let their sinful old selves tell them what to do live under that power of their sinful old selves. But those who let the Holy Spirit tell them what to do are under His power.
8.6: If your sinful old self is the boss over your mind, it leads to death. But if the Holy Spirit is the boss over your mind, it leads to life and peace.
8.7: The mind that thinks only of ways to please the sinful old self is fighting against God. It is not able to obey God’s Laws. It never can.
8.8: Those who do what their sinful old selves want to do cannot please God.
8.9: But you are not doing what your sinful old selves want you to do. You are doing what the Holy Spirit tells you to do, if you have God’s Spirit living in you. No one belongs to Christ if he does not have Christ’s Spirit in him.
8.10: If Christ is in you, your spirit lives because you are right with God, and yet your body is dead because of sin.
8.11: The Holy Spirit raised Jesus from the dead. If the same Holy Spirit lives in you, He will give life to your bodies in the same way.
8.12: So then, Christian brothers, we are not to do what our sinful old selves want us to do.
8.13: If you do what your sinful old selves want you to do, you will die in sin. But if, through the power of the Holy Spirit, you destroy those actions to which the body can be led, you will have life.
8.14: All those who are led by the Holy Spirit are sons of God.
8.15: You should not act like people who are owned by someone. They are always afraid. Instead, the Holy Spirit makes us His sons, and we can call to Him, “My Father.”
8.16: For the Holy Spirit speaks to us and tells our spirit that we are children of God.
8.17: If we are children of God, we will receive everything He has promised us. We will share with Christ all the things God has given to Him. But we must share His suffering if we are to share His shining-greatness.
8.18: I am sure that our suffering now cannot be compared to the shining-greatness that He is going to give us.
8.19: Everything that has been made in the world is waiting for the day when God will make His sons known.
8.20: Everything that has been made in the world is weak. It is not that the world wanted it to be that way. God allowed it to be that way. Yet there is hope.
8.21: Everything that has been made in the world will be set free from the power that can destroy. These will become free just as the children of God become free.
8.22: We know that everything on the earth cries out with pain the same as a woman giving birth to a child.
8.23: We also cry inside ourselves, even we who have received the Holy Spirit. The Holy Spirit is the first of God’s gifts to us. We are waiting to become His complete sons when our bodies are made free.
8.24: We were saved with this hope ahead of us. Now hope means we are waiting for something we do not have. How can a man hope for something he already has?
8.25: But if we hope for something we do not yet see, we must learn how to wait for it.
8.26: In the same way, the Holy Spirit helps us where we are weak. We do not know how to pray or what we should pray for, but the Holy Spirit prays to God for us with sounds that cannot be put into words.
8.27: God knows the hearts of men. He knows what the Holy Spirit is thinking. The Holy Spirit prays for those who belong to Christ the way God wants Him to pray.
8.28: We know that God makes all things work together for the good of those who love Him and are chosen to be a part of His plan.
8.29: God knew from the beginning who would put their trust in Him. So He chose them and made them to be like His Son. Christ was first and all those who belong to God are His brothers.
8.30: He called to Himself also those He chose. Those He called, He made right with Himself. Then He shared His shining-greatness with those He made right with Himself.
8.31: What can we say about all these things? Since God is for us, who can be against us?
8.32: God did not keep His own Son for Himself but gave Him for us all. Then with His Son, will He not give us all things?
8.33: Who can say anything against the people God has chosen? It is God Who says they are right with Himself.
8.34: Who then can say we are guilty? It was Christ Jesus Who died. He was raised from the dead. He is on the right side of God praying to Him for us.
8.35: Who can keep us away from the love of Christ? Can trouble or problems? Can suffering wrong from others or having no food? Can it be because of no clothes or because of danger or war?
8.36: The Holy Writings say, “Because of belonging to Jesus, we are in danger of being killed all day long. We are thought of as sheep that are ready to be killed.”
8.37: But we have power over all these things through Jesus Who loves us so much.
8.38: For I know that nothing can keep us from the love of God. Death cannot! Life cannot! Angels cannot! Leaders cannot! Any other power cannot! Hard things now or in the future cannot!
8.39: The world above or the world below cannot! Any other living thing cannot keep us away from the love of God which is ours through Christ Jesus our Lord.

9.1: I am telling the truth because I belong to Christ. The Holy Spirit tells my heart that I am not lying.
9.2: I have much sorrow. The pain in my heart never leaves.
9.3: I could even wish that I might be kept from being with Christ if that would help my people to be saved from the punishment of sin. They are of my own flesh and blood.
9.4: They are Jews and are the people God chose for Himself. He shared His shining-greatness with them and gave them His Law and a way to worship. They have His promises.
9.5: The early preachers came from this family. Christ Himself was born of flesh from this family and He is over all things. May God be honored and thanked forever. Let it be so.
9.6: I am not saying that God did not keep His promises. Not all the Jews are people God chose for Himself.
9.7: Not all of Abraham’s family are children of God. God told Abraham, “Only the family of Isaac will be called your family.”
9.8: This means that children born to Abraham are not all children of God. Only those that are born because of God’s promise to Abraham are His children.
9.9: This was the promise God made: “About this time next year I will come, and Sarah will have a son.”
9.10: Not only this, but there was Rebecca also. Rebecca gave birth to two sons at the same time. Both of them were sons of Isaac.
9.11: Even before the two sons were born, we see God’s plan of choosing. God could choose whom He wanted. It could not be changed because of anything the older son tried to do about it. It was before either one had done anything good or bad.
9.12: Rebecca was told, “The older son will work for the younger son.”
9.13: The Holy Writings say, “I loved Jacob, but hated Esau.”
9.14: What about it then? Can we say that God is not fair? No, not at all!
9.15: God said to Moses, “I will have loving-kindness and loving-pity for anyone I want to.”
9.16: These good things from God are not given to someone because he wants them or works to get them. They are given because of His loving-kindness.
9.17: The Holy Writings say to Pharaoh, “I made you leader for this reason: I used you to show My power. I used you to make My name known over all the world.”
9.18: So God has loving-kindness for those He wants to. He makes some have hard hearts if He wants to.
9.19: But you will ask me, “Why does God blame men for what they do? Who can go against what God wants?”
9.20: Who are you to talk back to God? A pot being made from clay does not talk to the man making it and say, “Why did you make me like this?”
9.21: The man making the pots has the right to use the clay as he wants to. He can make two pots from the same piece of clay. One can have an important use. The other one can be of little use.
9.22: It may be that God wants to show His power and His anger against sin. He waits a long time on some men who are ready to be destroyed.
9.23: God also wanted to show His shining-greatness to those He has given His loving-kindness. He made them ready for His shining-greatness from the beginning.
9.24: We are the ones He chose. He did not only choose Jews. He also chose some from among the people who are not Jews.
9.25: In the Book of Hosea He says, “Those who are not My people, I will call, ‘My people.’ Those who are not loved, I will call, ‘My loved ones.’”
9.26: “And where it said, ‘You are not my people,’ they will be called sons of the living God.”
9.27: Isaiah says this about the Jews, “Even if there are as many Jews as the sand by the sea, only a few of them will be saved from the punishment of sin.
9.28: For the Lord will do on earth what He says in His Word. He will work fast when He says what will happen here.”
9.29: Isaiah said also, “If God had not left some of the Jews, we would have all been destroyed like the people who lived in the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah.”
9.30: What are we to say about these things? The people who are not Jews were not made right with God by the Law. They were made right with God because they put their trust in Him.
9.31: The Jews tried to be right with God by obeying the Law, but they did not become right with God.
9.32: Why? Because they did not put their trust in God. They tried to be right with God by working for it. They tripped over the most important Stone (Christ).
9.33: The Holy Writings say, “See! I put in Jerusalem a Stone that people will trip over. It is a Rock that will make them fall. But the person who puts his trust in the Rock (Christ) will not be put to shame.”

10.1: Christian brothers, the desire of my heart and my prayer to God is that the Jews might be saved from the punishment of sin.
10.2: I know about them. They have a strong desire for God, but they do not know what they should about Him.
10.3: They have not known how God makes men right with Himself. Instead, they have tried to make their own way. They have not become right with God because they have not done what God said to do.
10.4: For Christ has put an end to the Law, so everyone who has put his trust in Christ is made right with God.
10.5: Moses writes that the man who obeys the Law has to live by it.
10.6: But when a man puts his trust in Christ, he is made right with God. You do not need to ask yourself, “Who will go up to heaven to bring Christ down?”
10.7: And you do not need to ask, “Who will go below and bring Christ up from the dead?”
10.8: This is what it says, “The Good News is near you. It is in your mouth and in your heart.” This Good News tells about putting your trust in Christ. This is what we preach to you.
10.9: If you say with your mouth that Jesus is Lord, and believe in your heart that God raised Him from the dead, you will be saved from the punishment of sin.
10.10: When we believe in our hearts, we are made right with God. We tell with our mouth how we were saved from the punishment of sin.
10.11: The Holy Writings say, “No one who puts his trust in Christ will ever be put to shame.”
10.12: There is no difference between the Jews and the people who are not Jews. They are all the same to the Lord. And He is Lord over all of them. He gives of His greatness to all who call on Him for help.
10.13: For everyone who calls on the name of the Lord will be saved from the punishment of sin.
10.14: But how can they call on Him if they have not put their trust in Him? And how can they put their trust in Him if they have not heard of Him? And how can they hear of Him unless someone tells them?
10.15: And how can someone tell them if he is not sent? The Holy Writings say, “The feet of those who bring the Good News are beautiful.”
10.16: But they have not all listened to the Good News. Isaiah says, “Lord, who believed what we told them?”
10.17: So then, faith comes to us by hearing the Good News. And the Good News comes by someone preaching it.
10.18: And so I ask, “Did they not hear?” For sure they did. The Holy Writings say, “Their voice was heard over all the earth. The Good News was told to the ends of the earth.”
10.19: Again I ask, “Did the Jews not understand?” First of all, Moses says, “I will make you jealous of those who are not a nation. I will make you angry with a foolish nation of people who do not understand.”
10.20: Isaiah says even stronger words, “I have been found by men who did not look for Me. I have shown Myself to those who were not asking for Me.”
10.21: This is what God says about the Jews, “All day long I held out my hand to a people who would not obey Me and who worked against Me.”

11.1: I ask then, “Has God put His people, the Jews, aside?” No, not at all! I myself am a Jew. Abraham was my early father. I am from the family group of Benjamin.
11.2: God has not put His people aside. He chose them from the beginning. Do you know what the Holy Writings say about Elijah? Do you know what Elijah said to God against the Jews?
11.3: He said, “Lord, they have killed Your early preachers. They have destroyed the places where You are worshiped. I am the only one left. They are trying to kill me.”
11.4: But what did God say to him? God said, “I still have 7,000 men. None of them have worshiped the false god Baal.”
11.5: It is the same now. A few of the Jews are being chosen because of God’s loving-favor.
11.6: If they are saved from the punishment of sin because of God’s loving-favor, it is nothing men have done to earn it. If men had earned it, then His loving-favor would not be a free gift.
11.7: This is the way it was. Many Jews did not get what they were looking for. Only those God chose received it. The hearts of the others were made hard. They could not understand it.
11.8: The Holy Writings say this about them, “God gave them hearts and minds that want to sleep. He gave them eyes that could not see. To this very day He gave them ears that could not hear.”
11.9: David said, “Let their table of food become a trap to hold them. Let it be a hole into which they fall and will suffer.
11.10: Let their eyes be closed so they cannot see. Keep their backs from being straight always because of their troubles.”
11.11: I ask then, “Did the Jews fall so they would be lost forever?” No, not at all! It means the people who are not Jews are able to be saved from the punishment of sin because the Jews sinned by not putting their trust in Christ. This made the Jews jealous of those who are not Jews.
11.12: The world received good things from God because of the sin of the Jews. Because the Jews did not receive God’s free gift, the people who are not Jews received good things from Him. Think how much more the world will receive when the Jews finish God’s plan by putting their trust in Christ!
11.13: I am speaking to you people who are not Jews. As long as I am a missionary to you, I want you to know how important my job is.
11.14: I do this so it will make my own people, the Jews, jealous. Then it may be that some will be saved from the punishment of sin.
11.15: Because the Jews have been put aside, many other people in the world have been saved from the punishment of sin. Think what it will be like when they are also gathered in. It will be like the dead coming back to life!
11.16: If the first loaf is holy, all the bread is holy. If the root is holy, all the branches are holy.
11.17: But some of the branches (who are the Jews) were broken off. You who are not Jews were put in the place where the branches had been broken off. Now you are sharing the rich root of the olive tree.
11.18: Do not be proud. Do not think you are better than the branches that were broken off. If you are proud, remember that you do not hold the root. It is the root that holds you.
11.19: You may say, “Branches were broken off to make room for me.”
11.20: It is true. They were broken off because they did not put their trust in Christ. And you are there only because of your faith. Do not be proud. Instead, be afraid.
11.21: God did not keep the first branches (who are the Jews) on the tree. Then watch, or He will not keep you on the tree.
11.22: We see how kind God is. It shows how hard He is also. He is hard on those who fall away. But He is kind to you if you keep on trusting Him. If you do not, He will cut you off.
11.23: If the Jews would put their trust in Christ, God would put them back into the tree. He has power to do that.
11.24: You people who are not Jews were cut off from a wild olive tree. Instead of being there, you were put into a garden olive tree which is not the right place for you to grow. It would be easy for God to put the Jews back onto their own olive tree because they are the branches that belong there.
11.25: Christian brothers, I want you to understand this truth which is no longer a secret. It will keep you from thinking you are so wise. Some Jews have become hard until the right amount of people who are not Jews come to God.
11.26: Then all the Jews will be saved, as the Holy Writings say, “The One Who saves from the punishment of sin will come out of Jerusalem. He will turn the Jews from doing sinful things.”
11.27: “And this is My promise to them when I take away their sins.”
11.28: The Jews are fighting against the Good News. Because they hate the Good News, it has helped you who are not Jews. But God still loves the Jews because He has chosen them and because of His promise to their early fathers.
11.29: God does not change His mind when He chooses men and gives them His gifts.
11.30: At one time you did not obey God. But when the Jews did not receive God’s gift, you did. It was because they did not obey.
11.31: The Jews will not obey now. God’s loving-kindness to you will some day turn them to Him. Then the Jews may have His loving-kindness also.
11.32: God has said that all men have broken His Law. But He will show loving-kindness on all of them.
11.33: God’s riches are so great! The things He knows and His wisdom are so deep! No one can understand His thoughts. No one can understand His ways.
11.34: The Holy Writings say, “Who knows the mind of the Lord? Who is able to tell Him what to do?”
11.35: “Who has given first to God, that God should pay him back?”
11.36: Everything comes from Him. His power keeps all things together. All things are made for Him. May He be honored forever. Let it be so.

12.1: Christian brothers, I ask you from my heart to give your bodies to God because of His loving-kindness to us. Let your bodies be a living and holy gift given to God. He is pleased with this kind of gift. This is the true worship that you should give Him.
12.2: Do not act like the sinful people of the world. Let God change your life. First of all, let Him give you a new mind. Then you will know what God wants you to do. And the things you do will be good and pleasing and perfect.
12.3: God has given me His loving-favor. This helps me write these things to you. I ask each one of you not to think more of himself than he should think. Instead, think in the right way toward yourself by the faith God has given you.
12.4: Our bodies are made up of many parts. None of these parts have the same use.
12.5: There are many people who belong to Christ. And yet, we are one body which is Christ’s. We are all different but we depend on each other.
12.6: We all have different gifts that God has given to us by His loving-favor. We are to use them. If someone has the gift of preaching the Good News, he should preach. He should use the faith God has given him.
12.7: If someone has the gift of helping others, then he should help. If someone has the gift of teaching, he should teach.
12.8: If someone has the gift of speaking words of comfort and help, he should speak. If someone has the gift of sharing what he has, he should give from a willing heart. If someone has the gift of leading other people, he should lead them. If someone has the gift of showing kindness to others, he should be happy as he does it.
12.9: Be sure your love is true love. Hate what is sinful. Hold on to whatever is good.
12.10: Love each other as Christian brothers. Show respect for each other.
12.11: Do not be lazy but always work hard. Work for the Lord with a heart full of love for Him.
12.12: Be happy in your hope. Do not give up when trouble comes. Do not let anything stop you from praying.
12.13: Share what you have with Christian brothers who are in need. Give meals and a place to stay to those who need it.
12.14: Pray and give thanks for those who make trouble for you. Yes, pray for them instead of talking against them.
12.15: Be happy with those who are happy. Be sad with those who are sad.
12.16: Live in peace with each other. Do not act or think with pride. Be happy to be with poor people. Keep yourself from thinking you are so wise.
12.17: When someone does something bad to you, do not pay him back with something bad. Try to do what all men know is right and good.
12.18: As much as you can, live in peace with all men.
12.19: Christian brothers, never pay back someone for the bad he has done to you. Let the anger of God take care of the other person. The Holy Writings say, “I will pay back to them what they should get, says the Lord.”
12.20: “If the one who hates you is hungry, feed him. If he is thirsty, give him water. If you do that, you will be making him more ashamed of himself.”
12.21: Do not let sin have power over you. Let good have power over sin!

13.1: Every person must obey the leaders of the land. There is no power given but from God, and all leaders are allowed by God.
13.2: The person who does not obey the leaders of the land is working against what God has done. Anyone who does that will be punished.
13.3: Those who do right do not have to be afraid of the leaders. Those who do wrong are afraid of them. Do you want to be free from fear of them? Then do what is right. You will be respected instead.
13.4: Leaders are God’s servants to help you. If you do wrong, you should be afraid. They have the power to punish you. They work for God. They do what God wants done to those who do wrong.
13.5: You must obey the leaders of the land, not only to keep from God’s anger, but so your own heart will have peace.
13.6: It is right for you to pay taxes because the leaders of the land are servants for God who care for these things.
13.7: Pay taxes to whom taxes are to be paid. Be afraid of those you should fear. Respect those you should respect.
13.8: Do not owe anyone anything, but love each other. Whoever loves his neighbor has done what the Law says to do.
13.9: The Law says, “You must not do any sex sin. You must not kill another person. You must not steal. You must not tell a lie about another person. You must not want something someone else has.” The Law also says that these and many other Laws are brought together in one Law, “You must love your neighbor as yourself.”
13.10: Anyone who loves his neighbor will do no wrong to him. You keep the Law with love.
13.11: There is another reason for doing what is right. You know what time it is. It is time for you to wake up from your sleep. The time when we will be taken up to be with Christ is not as far off as when we first put our trust in Him.
13.12: Night is almost gone. Day is almost here. We must stop doing the sinful things that are done in the dark. We must put on all the things God gives us to fight with for the day.
13.13: We must act all the time as if it were day. Keep away from wild parties and do not be drunk. Keep yourself free from sex sins and bad actions. Do not fight or be jealous.
13.14: Let every part of you belong to the Lord Jesus Christ. Do not allow your weak thoughts to lead you into sinful actions.

14.1: If there is someone whose faith is weak, be kind and receive him. Do not argue about what he thinks.
14.2: One man believes he may eat everything. Another man with weak faith eats only vegetables.
14.3: The man who eats everything should not think he is better than the one who eats only vegetables. The man who eats only vegetables should not say the other man is wrong, because God has received him.
14.4: Who are you to tell another person’s servant if he is right or wrong? It is to his owner that he does good or bad. The Lord is able to help him.
14.5: One man thinks one day is more important than another. Another man thinks every day is the same. Every man must be sure in his own mind.
14.6: The man who worships on a special day does it to honor the Lord. The man who eats meat does it to honor the Lord. He gives thanks to God for what he eats. The other man does not eat meat. In this way, he honors the Lord. He gives thanks to God also.
14.7: No one lives for himself alone. No one dies for himself alone.
14.8: If we live, it is for the Lord. If we die, it is for the Lord. If we live or die, we belong to the Lord.
14.9: Christ died and lived again. This is why He is the Lord of the living and of the dead.
14.10: Why do you try to say your Christian brother is right or wrong? Why do you hate your Christian brother? We will all stand before God to be judged by Him.
14.11: The Holy Writings say, “As I live, says the Lord, every knee will bow before Me. And every tongue will say that I am God.”
14.12: Everyone of us will give an answer to God about himself.
14.13: So you should stop saying that you think other people are wrong. Instead, decide to live so that your Christian brother will not have a reason to trip or fall into sin because of you.
14.14: Christ has made me know that everything in itself is clean. But if a person thinks something is not clean, then to him it is not clean.
14.15: If your Christian brother is hurt because of some foods you eat, then you are no longer living by love. Do not destroy the man for whom Christ died by the food you eat.
14.16: Do not let what is good for you be talked about as bad.
14.17: For the holy nation of God is not food and drink. It is being right with God. It is peace and joy given by the Holy Spirit.
14.18: If you follow Christ in these things, God will be happy with you. Men will think well of you also.
14.19: Work for the things that make peace and help each other become stronger Christians.
14.20: Do not destroy what God has done just because of some food. All food is good to eat. But it is wrong to eat anything that will make someone fall into sin.
14.21: Do not eat meat or drink wine or do anything else if it would make your Christian brother fall into sin.
14.22: Keep the faith you have between yourself and God. A man is happy if he knows he is doing right.
14.23: But if he has doubts about the food he eats, God says he is guilty when he eats it. It is because he is eating without faith. Anything that is not done in faith is sin.

15.1: We who have strong faith should help those who are weak. We should not live to please ourselves.
15.2: Each of us should live to please his neighbor. This will help him grow in faith.
15.3: Even Christ did not please Himself. The Holy Writings say, “The sharp words spoken against you fell on Me.”
15.4: Everything that was written in the Holy Writings long ago was written to teach us. By not giving up, God’s Word gives us strength and hope.
15.5: Now the God Who helps you not to give up and gives you strength will help you think so you can please each other as Christ Jesus did.
15.6: Then all of you together can thank the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ.
15.7: Receive each other as Christ received you. This will honor God.
15.8: Christ came to help the Jews. This proved that God had told the truth to their early fathers. This proved that God would do what He promised.
15.9: This was done so the people who are not Jews can thank God for His loving-kindness. The Holy Writings say, “This is why I will give thanks to you among the people who are not Jews. I will sing to Your name.”
15.10: It says also, “You who are not Jews, be happy with His people, the Jews.”
15.11: And, “Honor and give thanks to the Lord, you who are not Jews. Let everyone honor Him.”
15.12: And Isaiah says, “There will be One from the family of Jesse Who will be a leader over the people who are not Jews. Their hope will be in Him.”
15.13: Our hope comes from God. May He fill you with joy and peace because of your trust in Him. May your hope grow stronger by the power of the Holy Spirit.
15.14: I am sure you are wise in all things and full of much good. You are able to help and teach each other.
15.15: I have written to you with strong words about some things. I have written so you would remember. God helped me write like this.
15.16: I am able to write these things because God made me a missionary to the people who are not Jews. I work as a servant of Jesus Christ. I preach the Good News of God so the people who are not Jews may be as a gift to God. The Holy Spirit will set them apart so God will be pleased with them.
15.17: I have reason to be proud of my work for God. It is because I belong to Christ Jesus.
15.18: I can only speak of what Christ has done through me. I have helped the people who are not Jews to obey Him. I have done it by words and by living with them.
15.19: God showed them His power through me. The Holy Spirit did powerful works through me in front of them. From Jerusalem to the country of Illyricum I have preached the Good News of Christ.
15.20: It is my desire to preach the Good News where it has never been preached. I want to preach only where Christ is not known.
15.21: The Holy Writings say, “Those who have never known about Him will see. And those who have never heard about Him will understand.”
15.22: This is why I have been kept many times from coming to you.
15.23: But now I am finished with my work here. I have been wanting to come and visit you for many years.
15.24: I hope I can now. I am making plans to go to the country of Spain. On my way there I will stop and visit you. After I have had the joy of visiting you for awhile, you can help me on my way again.
15.25: But now I am going to Jerusalem to hand the Christians the gift of money.
15.26: The churches in the countries of Macedonia and Greece have decided to give money to help some of the poor Christians in Jerusalem.
15.27: They wanted to do it. They should help them in this way because they owe much to the Christians in Jerusalem. The Jews shared the Good News with the people who are not Jews. For this reason, they should share what they can with the Jews.
15.28: I will hand this gift of money to them. Then I will stop to see you on my way to the country of Spain.
15.29: I know that when I come to you, Christ will give me much good to share with you.
15.30: I ask you from my heart, Christian brothers, to pray much for me. I ask this in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.
15.31: Pray that God will keep me safe from the people in the country of Judea who are not Christians. Pray also that the work I am to do for the Christians in Jerusalem will help them.
15.32: Then I will be coming to you if God wants me to come. I will be full of joy, and together we can have some rest.
15.33: May our God Who gives us peace, be with you all. Let it be so.

16.1: I want to let you know about our Christian sister Phoebe. She is a helper in the church in the city of Cenchrea.
16.2: The Christians should receive her as a sister who belongs to the Lord. Help her any way you can. She has helped many people and has helped me also.
16.3: Greet Priscilla and Aquila. They worked with me for Christ.
16.4: They almost died for me. I am thankful for them. All the churches that were started among the people who are not Jews are thankful for them also.
16.5: Greet the church that worships in their house. Greet Epaenetus, my much-loved friend. He was the first Christian in the countries of Asia.
16.6: Greet Mary. She worked hard for you.
16.7: Greet Andronicus and Junias. They are from my family and were in prison with me. They put their trust in Christ before I did. They have been respected missionaries.
16.8: Greet Ampliatus. He is a much-loved Christian brother.
16.9: Greet Urbanus. He worked with us for Christ. Greet Stachys, my much-loved friend.
16.10: Greet Apelles. He proved he was faithful to Christ. Greet all the family of Aristobulus.
16.11: Greet Herodian. He is one of my family. Greet the Christians in the family of Narcissus.
16.12: Greet Tryphaena and Tryphosa and Persis. They are all much-loved workmen for the Lord.
16.13: Greet Rufus and his mother. She was like a mother to me. Rufus is a good Christian.
16.14: Greet Asyncritus and Phlegon and Hermes and Patrobas and Hermas and all the Christians with them.
16.15: Greet Philologus and Julia and Nereus and his sister and Olympas and all the Christians with them.
16.16: Greet each other with a kiss of holy love. All the churches here greet you.
16.17: I ask you, Christian brothers, watch out for those who make trouble and start fights. Keep your eye on those who work against the teaching you received. Keep away from them.
16.18: Men like that are not working for our Lord Jesus Christ. They are chained to their own desires. With soft words they say things people want to hear. People are fooled by them.
16.19: Everyone knows you have obeyed the teaching you received. I am happy with you because of this. But I want you to be wise about good things and pure about sinful things.
16.20: God, Who is our peace, will soon crush Satan under your feet. May the loving-favor of our Lord Jesus be yours.
16.21: Timothy, my helper, greets you. Lucius and Jason and Sosipater from my family say hello also.
16.22: I, Tertius, who am writing this letter for Paul, greet you as a Christian brother.
16.23: Gaius is the man taking care of me. The church meets here in his house. He greets you. Erastus, the man who takes care of the money for the city, says hello and Quartus does also. He is a Christian brother.
16.24: May you have loving-favor from our Lord Jesus Christ. Let it be so.
16.25: We give honor to God. He is able to make you strong as I preach from the Holy Writings about Jesus Christ. It was a secret hidden from the beginning of the world.
16.26: But now it is for us to know. The early preachers wrote about it. God says it is to be preached to all the people of the world so men can put their trust in God and obey Him.
16.27: May God, Who only is wise, be honored forever through our Lord Jesus Christ. Let it be so.
